By adding zeroes
@hussainalmalker5254   front or back
Data can be transmitted  in bit oriented forms like 4 ,16,32,64,  According to its architecture data can be transmitted  Hence even if there is odd no of bits  They can be added by zeros

If the checksum (redundant bits) itself gets damaged,  it will result in the final sum not being equal to 0, just like when the actual data (the other bits) gets damaged. So, when the checksum is damaged, regardless of whether the actual data itself was damaged or not, the received data is discarded.

I know I'm years late but the reason is:  For example the sum comes out to be 001100 we send data + complement of sum = 001100 + 110011 = 111111  Even if the carry wraps around, sum + complement would always result in all ones

If the checksum gets corrupted, It will not match the data it is associated with, meaning the message is provably corrupted in some way. It is mathematically impossible for two identical check-sums to be associated with different data with respect to the length of the bytes.
@fgc_rewind  so a fraudulent check sum wouldn't be possible to produce unless it came from the actual data?

Suppose u have 3 segments of data.. 1000 1000 1010 now add it and find complement. Now after transmission, the data become 1000 1010 1000 (i.e the 2nd and 3rd segment are distorted in such a way that it seems like their value is interchanged. this is very rare situation but chances are there) now if u sum using Checksum in receiver side u will get all 1's. Thus an error has occurred but checksum could not detect it.
@RahulDaslp  what's the meaning of odd number bit? is it "3" segment? or total of binary to decimal? thankyou

If you are referring to 1s complement, the way it works is just turning each 1 ==> 0 and 0 ==> 1. But if you are referring to how he does the addition process. You can search a topic called Binary Addition. :)
